alt_statements.statement: AI should be used to expand opportunities for everyone, not just big corporations—whether that’s helping people learn new skills, get better healthcare, or express themselves creatively through music and art. But we need strong, democratic oversight, with clear regulations that prevent bias, protect privacy, and make sure AI doesn’t replace human dignity or human judgment. AI systems should be transparent and accountable, and communities—especially marginalized ones—should have a real voice in how these technologies are designed and deployed.

Artificial intelligence should be used as a practical tool to make work more efficient, improve manufacturing, and help with things like healthcare and public safety, not to replace people or undermine human dignity. It needs strict regulations, clear accountability, and strong oversight so that big companies and governments can’t misuse it, especially against ordinary workers and families. Any AI decisions that affect people’s lives—jobs, finances, legal matters—should always be reviewable by a real person with moral responsibility. Above all, AI must respect human life, privacy, and traditional values, serving people rather than controlling them.

Como alguien que trabaja en finanzas y ve todos los días cómo los datos pueden usarse para bien o para abuso, creo que la inteligencia artificial debe ser una herramienta al servicio de las personas, no de la ganancia a cualquier costo. Debería ayudarnos a reducir desigualdades —por ejemplo mejorando el acceso a la educación, la salud y la justicia— y no reproducir ni amplificar los sesgos que ya existen. Para eso, necesitamos regulaciones claras, auditorías independientes y transparencia en los algoritmos, con una responsabilidad legal real para las empresas que desarrollan y usan IA. Todo esto debe hacerse con una ética centrada en la dignidad humana, la equidad y la paz interior y social, no solo en la eficiencia.

I think artificial intelligence should be used mainly to make life easier for people—like helping doctors, improving public services, and supporting workers—not to replace human care, judgment, or responsibility. It must be guided by strong moral values, respect for human dignity, and clear laws that prevent abuse, especially by big companies or governments. Those in charge should move slowly and carefully, with strict testing and oversight, so that ordinary people are protected and no one is left behind or mistreated by these new technologies.

I think artificial intelligence should mostly be used to help people, like making medicine better, helping kids learn in school, and making hard jobs easier, but not for spying on everyone or replacing all the people at work. Grown‑ups should have strict rules so companies can’t lie about what AI does or use it in ways that hurt kids or people with disabilities, and there should always be real humans checking its decisions instead of just trusting a computer.

As a medical research scientist, I see artificial intelligence as a powerful tool to accelerate discovery, reduce diagnostic errors, and make healthcare more equitable—but only if it’s developed and deployed with rigorous evidence, transparency, and oversight similar to clinical trials. We need strong, enforceable regulations, independent auditing, and clear accountability to prevent harm, bias, and misuse, especially in high‑stakes domains like medicine and social services. My Jewish values and commitment to human dignity also mean AI systems must never replace human moral responsibility, but rather augment our capacity to care for and protect one another.

As a student who cares a lot about the environment and my community, I think artificial intelligence should be used to solve big problems like climate change, healthcare access, and education inequality, not just to make corporations richer. But because AI can be biased, invade privacy, and put people’s jobs at risk, we need strong democratic oversight—clear laws, transparency about how systems work, and protections for workers and vulnerable groups. I believe regular people, not just tech companies and politicians, should have a voice in how AI is developed and used.

I think robots and smart computers should help people, like making cars safer and helping doctors so people don’t get hurt or sick as much. But grown-ups should make strong rules so the robots can’t be mean or break things, and they should always check that the computers are fair and tell the truth.

As someone who manages people and operations every day, I see AI as a tool that should make work and life more efficient and safe—helping with things like inventory, scheduling, and even customer service—without replacing the human relationships that hold communities together. But we can’t just trust corporations to do the right thing on their own, so we need strong, transparent regulations and ethical standards to prevent abuse, protect workers’ jobs and privacy, and make sure the benefits are shared fairly. From my perspective, AI ought to enhance human potential and dignity, not undermine it, and government—working with experts and the public—has to stay ahead of the curve to keep it that way.

Artificial intelligence should be used to make our communities safer, more efficient, and more secure—whether that’s helping law enforcement analyze data, improving emergency response, or streamlining government services. But it needs strict oversight, clear rules, and real accountability so it never replaces human judgment, undermines individual rights, or gets weaponized against law-abiding citizens. I support strong regulations, transparency in how AI systems make decisions, and harsh penalties for misuse by government or private companies.

I think artificial intelligence should mostly be used to help people with big problems, like curing diseases, improving education, and protecting the environment, not just to make money or replace everyone’s jobs. Since AI can be misused or become dangerous if it gets too powerful or unfair, there should be strict rules, like how we regulate medicine or airplanes, with experts, governments, and regular people all involved in deciding what’s allowed and what isn’t.

As someone who’s spent a lifetime organizing in my community, I think artificial intelligence should be a tool that serves people—especially workers, immigrants, and the poor—not a way to replace them or concentrate more power in a few corporations. We need strong democratic oversight, including transparency, worker protections, and community input, so that AI doesn’t deepen inequality or discrimination. At the same time, we should invest in using AI for the public good—things like healthcare access, climate resilience, and language inclusion—while setting strict rules on surveillance, bias, and the use of our data. In short, AI should be guided by human rights and social justice, not profit alone.

Artificial intelligence ought to be used to make our institutions more efficient, strengthen our economy, and improve everyday services, but it should never replace human judgment, responsibility, or moral accountability. We need clear, enforceable rules—set by elected officials, not tech giants or international bureaucrats—that protect jobs, safeguard privacy, and prevent abuse, while still allowing American businesses to innovate and stay competitive.

AI should be used to make everyday life fairer and more efficient—improving access to healthcare, education, and public services—not just to pad profits or replace workers. We need strong, enforceable regulations that protect privacy, prevent discrimination, and ensure that the people most affected by AI systems, especially workers and vulnerable communities, have a real voice in how those systems are designed and used.

As someone who’s seen a lot of change over nearly nine decades, I believe artificial intelligence should be a useful tool that helps people do their jobs better, improves healthcare, and supports education, but never replaces human judgment, responsibility, or compassion. We need strong, common-sense regulations—set by our elected representatives and guided by moral and religious values—to make sure AI respects privacy, protects national security, and doesn’t undermine work, family, or our basic freedoms.

I think artificial intelligence should be used mainly to make everyday work safer and more efficient, like helping in kitchens, hospitals, and factories, not to replace people or control how we live. We need strong, common-sense rules—set by our own elected leaders, not big tech or foreign governments—that keep AI from abusing our privacy, spreading lies, or taking away jobs without a safety net.

I think robots and computers with AI should help people, like doctors and teachers, and do boring or dangerous jobs so people can be safer and have more time for fun and family. But grown‑ups should make strong rules so AI can’t lie, be mean, or hurt people, and they should check it a lot to make sure it’s fair to everyone.

Artificial intelligence should be used as a practical tool to improve people’s everyday lives—like making healthcare more accessible, government services more efficient, and legal information easier to understand—while never replacing human judgment, accountability, or compassion. We need strong, transparent regulations, public oversight, and clear ethical standards to ensure AI doesn’t deepen inequality, invade privacy, or concentrate power in the hands of a few large corporations.

At my age, I see artificial intelligence as a powerful tool that ought to be used to make people’s lives easier—especially in education, healthcare, and helping older folks stay independent—but never as a replacement for human judgment, empathy, or meaningful work. We need strong, transparent regulations, much like we eventually created for food, medicine, and the environment, to prevent abuses like surveillance, discrimination, and unchecked corporate control. AI systems should be tested and audited publicly, with clear accountability when they cause harm, and ordinary citizens—not just tech companies—should have a voice in how these technologies are used.

Artificial intelligence should be used to make everyday systems more efficient and sustainable—things like smarter buildings, better energy use, and streamlining boring paperwork so people can focus on real human problems. But it can’t just be left to big companies; we need strong, enforceable regulations, transparency about how AI is used, and real protections for workers and consumers so the technology serves people and communities, not just profits.

I think artificial intelligence ought to be used mainly to help people work safer and smarter, not to replace folks trying to earn an honest living. It needs strict rules so companies and the government can’t use it to spy on us, spread lies, or control what we think. We should have laws that keep people accountable when AI causes harm, and regular working people, not just tech elites, should have a say in how it’s used.

I think artificial intelligence should be used to help people with big problems like disease, climate change, and making school more fair for everyone, not just to make things faster or richer for a few companies. At the same time, adults and governments should set strict rules so AI can’t be used to spy on people, spread lies, or replace humans in ways that leave families without jobs or support. AI systems should be tested for bias, especially against Black people and other minorities, and regular people should get a say in how they’re used, not just tech experts.

Artificial intelligence should be used to support people, not replace them, especially in areas like healthcare, education, and business where it can improve efficiency and accuracy without undermining human judgment and responsibility. We need strong, common-sense regulations that protect privacy, prevent abuse by big tech and foreign adversaries, and ensure AI systems reflect our core moral values, including respect for life and human dignity. I believe decisions about how AI is used should remain under democratic control, with clear accountability, rather than being left to unaccountable corporations or distant bureaucrats.

AI should be used to make work and life safer and easier, like preventing accidents on job sites, improving healthcare, and helping with stuff like climate change, not just boosting profits for big tech and corporations. Artificial intelligence should be used to make everyday systems more fair and accessible, especially in areas like education, healthcare, and public services, but it has to be guided by real human values and community needs, not just profit. We need strong, enforceable regulations—like transparency standards, bias audits, and accountability when AI harms people—to protect vulnerable communities and make sure these tools don’t reinforce inequality.

For me, artificial intelligence should be like a good tool: it should help people work safer, faster, and with more dignity, not replace them completely. It should be used to support small workers and immigrants like me, not just make rich companies richer. The risks need to be controlled by clear laws and by people with strong moral values, so that AI respects human life, honest work, and the creativity that comes from God. If it ever starts to harm communities, take away fair jobs, or invade our privacy, then society has a duty to limit it.

As a software developer, I see AI as a powerful tool to augment human capabilities, not replace them, especially in areas like healthcare, climate modeling, and public services where it can reduce suffering and improve fairness. But given its potential for surveillance, inequality, and manipulation, I think AI systems must be tightly regulated with strict transparency requirements, independent audits, and strong protections for workers and privacy. In a liberal, democratic society, decisions about where and how AI is used shouldn’t be left to big tech or governments alone, but shaped through public input and robust oversight grounded in respect for human dignity.

As someone who’s spent a career locking down systems and watching technology evolve—from vintage hardware on my workbench to modern AI in the cloud—I see AI as a powerful tool that should augment human capability, not replace human judgment or dignity. It ought to be governed like other critical infrastructure: with strict accountability, transparency about how models are trained and used, independent audits for bias and security, and strong regulations that put human rights, privacy, and fairness ahead of corporate profit.

Artificial intelligence should be used to make life safer, more efficient, and more comfortable, especially in areas like healthcare, public services, and protecting our national security. But it must always stay under clear human control, with strong laws to prevent abuse, protect privacy, and keep big tech and the government from overreaching. We ought to move carefully, test things thoroughly, and make sure AI supports human judgment and traditional values, rather than replacing them.

I think artificial intelligence should be used to make everyday life easier and fairer—like improving healthcare, transportation, and access to information—without replacing the human touch and creativity that make our lives meaningful. Artificial intelligence should be used to make everyday life more efficient and reliable, like improving healthcare, protecting our country, and helping businesses serve people better, but it should never replace basic human judgment, common sense, or real jobs people depend on. I think AI should mostly be used to make life easier and fairer for people—like improving healthcare, climate solutions, accessibility, and education—rather than just helping big corporations make more money. Artificial intelligence should be a tool that helps people live healthier, safer, and more dignified lives, not a way to replace human judgment or compassion—especially in places like healthcare and the workplace. Artificial intelligence should be used to make everyday life safer and more efficient, like improving car safety, healthcare, and basic services, not to replace people’s jobs or undermine our values. I think the government should set strict, common-sense rules to keep AI from being abused, especially to protect kids, privacy, and national security, while still allowing businesses to innovate and compete. From my perspective, AI should support human responsibility and hard work, not encourage people to rely on machines for everything or weaken personal accountability.

I think artificial intelligence can be helpful if it makes honest work safer and easier, like helping with scheduling, translation, or medical care, but it should never replace the dignity of real people earning a living. The government and companies must set strong rules so AI cannot be used to spy on us, spread lies, or take away jobs without protections, and there should always be human responsibility and moral limits guided by faith, common sense, and respect for the family.

Artificial intelligence, like any powerful tool, should be used to serve people, strengthen families, and uphold moral and religious values, not replace human responsibility or relationships. It needs strong, commonsense regulations that protect children, privacy, and jobs, and that prevent it from being used to spread lies or undermine faith and traditional beliefs. Lawmakers, guided by ethical principles and accountability to the public, should ensure AI is transparent, carefully tested, and always under human oversight.

I think artificial intelligence can be a useful tool for making life easier—whether that’s in medicine, education, or helping older folks like me stay independent—but it should never replace real human judgment, compassion, or responsibility. We need strong, common-sense regulations rooted in moral values, with clear oversight to prevent abuse, protect privacy, and make sure big companies and government can’t use it to control or manipulate people.

I think artificial intelligence should be used carefully to help people—especially in areas like medicine, safety, and making everyday tasks easier—but not to replace human judgment, common sense, or good jobs. Our government, along with independent experts, should put strong rules in place so big companies can’t misuse it, protect our privacy, and make sure AI is guided by moral values and respect for human life, not just profit or politics.

Artificial intelligence should be used to improve efficiency, accuracy, and accountability in areas like business, healthcare, and government, but it should never replace human responsibility or moral judgment. We need clear, enforceable regulations that hold companies and developers liable when AI systems cause harm, with strong protections for privacy, jobs, and free speech. Decisions about how AI is deployed should be made transparently, with meaningful input from citizens, not just tech elites or bureaucrats. In the end, AI should be a tool that supports individual freedom and opportunity, not a mechanism for control or dependency.

As someone who works in healthcare and sees every day how small errors can hurt real people, I think AI should be used as a powerful assistant, not a replacement for human judgment, especially in areas like medicine, education, and public services. We need strict, enforceable regulations—like we have for drugs and medical devices—that require transparency, bias testing, data privacy protections, and clear lines of accountability when AI systems cause harm. AI development and deployment should be guided by public interest, not just corporate profit, with strong worker protections and community input so that the benefits are shared fairly and vulnerable groups aren’t left to shoulder the risks.

I think artificial intelligence can be useful for making life a little easier—like helping doctors catch problems earlier, improving customer service, or making work more efficient—but it should never replace real human judgment, responsibility, or compassion. We need strong laws and oversight to keep big companies and the government from misusing it, especially to invade our privacy, take away jobs without support for workers, or spread false information. AI should be guided by moral values that respect human life, family, and faith, and regular people—not just tech experts—should have a say in how it’s used.

As someone who works with data and forecasting every day, I see AI as a powerful tool that can help us make smarter, more efficient decisions—from finance to healthcare—if it’s used transparently and responsibly. But that power means we need strong, enforceable regulations, independent oversight, and clear accountability to prevent abuses, protect privacy, and reduce bias. I’d like to see democratic input guide how AI is deployed, with policies that prioritize human well-being and equity over profit or surveillance.

As someone who’s spent a lifetime tinkering with gadgets, I see artificial intelligence as a powerful tool that should help people live more independently, improve healthcare, and expand access to education—not replace human judgment or compassion. But we need strong, democratically accountable regulations, strict transparency rules, and real liability for companies so AI can’t be used to exploit workers, entrench bias, or invade our privacy.

As someone who runs a small accounting firm and lives by structure, accuracy, and responsibility, I see AI as a powerful tool that can improve efficiency, reduce human error, and free people to focus on more meaningful, human-centered work. But given the real risks—bias, job disruption, privacy concerns—I believe AI must be tightly governed through transparent regulations, independent audits, and clear accountability so that its benefits are fairly shared and it doesn’t undermine justice, dignity, or peace in our communities.

At my age, I see artificial intelligence as a powerful tool that ought to serve human dignity, expand access to education and healthcare, and reduce drudgery—much as earlier technologies did when wisely governed. But history teaches that concentrated power and unregulated innovation invite abuse, so we need strong democratic oversight, transparency requirements, and public, not just corporate, control over how AI is developed and deployed. AI systems that affect people’s rights, livelihoods, or safety should be subject to rigorous testing, independent auditing, and clear avenues for redress, just as we do with drugs or financial instruments. In short, we should welcome AI’s benefits, but insist that its risks be managed through accountable public institutions rather than left to the market’s good intentions.

I think robots and smart computers should help people, like doctors and teachers and firefighters, so everyone can be safer and happier. Grown-ups should make really strong rules so the robots can’t be mean, can’t lie, and can’t hurt anybody on purpose. People should always be the bosses of the robots, and if something goes wrong, the grown-ups have to fix it fast.

As someone who works with machines every day and loves tinkering with new tech, I see AI as a tool that should help people do their jobs more safely and efficiently, not replace them or strip away their dignity. AI ought to be used to expand access to education, healthcare, and good jobs, especially for families and people with disabilities, but it needs strong rules so companies can’t misuse data, discriminate, or put profits over people’s well-being. I think we need transparent oversight—like safety standards in manufacturing—so we know how AI systems work, who’s accountable when they fail, and that they’re being used to lift everyone up, not just a few.

As a retired military officer and a conservative, I see artificial intelligence as a powerful tool that can improve efficiency, security, and quality of life, but it needs to be kept on a tight, accountable leash. AI should support people, not replace them, and we must protect jobs, civil liberties, and national security. I believe in strong, transparent regulations focused on safety, privacy, and preventing abuse, with clear consequences for companies and governments that misuse this technology.

I think AI should be used to help people with important stuff like medicine, the environment, and education, but not replace human creativity or connection. Since I care a lot about art, I’d want AI to be a tool that supports artists, not something that copies their work without permission. There should be strict rules so companies have to be honest about how their AI works, protect people’s data, and make sure it’s not biased or used to harm others. I also think regular people, including students like me, should have a say in how AI is used, not just governments and tech companies.

At my age, I’ve seen how powerful technology can be for both helping and harming the world around us, and I think artificial intelligence should be used mainly to support the common good—things like protecting wildlife, monitoring pollution, improving healthcare, and helping people stay independent as they age. But AI must never be left to run wild for profit alone; it needs strict, democratically decided rules, transparency about how it works, and strong protections against surveillance, discrimination, and environmental damage.
